I've felt many a disappointment getting take out and it arriving to be a sloppy, slimy, msg-filled mess. But, when I do have a hankering for some of the good stuff I make sure to head to this place. One of the better (if not top) places to get authentic, delicious, not over-seasoned chinese food. Their won ton soup is in a wonderful broth and the egg rolls are perfectly fried. Huge fan as well of their chicken dishes. Seafood here is excellent and can recommend any of it. If you're looking for the weird stuff (Jellyfish, anyone?) this is the place to go. Service is friendly, but not suffocating. Top it all off with some of their wonderful tea and you will definitely have an enjoyable meal!

Although the star-rating does not reflect, I'd give this place a 3.5.   This Cantonese restaurant is nicely appointed.  The architecture of the building is beautiful, and the interior design is quite nice for a Chinatown restaurant (and they have white table cloth).   Unlike other restaurants in Chinatown, however, this restaurant caters to primarily non-Chinese crowd.  We were the only Chinese table in the dining room that night.  We were handed a regular menu and a "chef's special" menu.  Upon reading the menu, I realized that they were essentially an American-Chinese food menu (i.e. sweet-and-sour, kung-pao...) and authentic Chinese food menu respectively.  I was slightly disappointed because the authentic menu was rather limited, while the American menu was more expansive. That being said, the few dishes we got were not bad at all.  Service was also good.  And the ambiance of the place is probably one of the nicest in Chinatown.  If you are looking to explore Chinatown, this place is a good start - watered-down but still authentic and nice.  If you are Chinese, stick to the Chef's Special Menu then you'd have yourself an authentic Canto fare.

I've been here twice and both times it was outstanding. This place has something to please both those stuck to their tried and true Americanized "Chinese" food (the big menu), and those wanting to try something new and perhaps less Americanized (little yellow menu). Honestly, if you are going to go to China town, I suggest you get out of your Sesame Chicken and Egg Roll rut.  First time I came here I had the Singapore noodles - awesome sauce, lots of veggies and meat, and most memorably HUGE chunks of Shiitake mushroom. The salt and pepper tofu was the surprise winner of the meal - tiny fried tofu pillows packed with flavor.  The second time I had the scallops with asparagus. Did you ever see Return of the Dragon where the restaurant owners have to call in Bruce Lee to fight the mob guy trying to extort money from them? I'm convinced the same thing happened here, except the mob guys were giant alien asparagus. Because that is the only way I can explain to myself how they managed to put such GIGANTIC chunks of asparagus in this dish! (Perfectly cooked mind you). The sauce complimented the flavors of the scallop and asparagus excellently, and the dish was just outstanding.  The service here has always been incredibly friendly and helpful. And every time I've gone, I've been surrounded by happy families and large groups of people enjoying a pleasant meal.  I know there are lots of places to try in Chinatown, but this place just keeps pulling me back in. But, thankfully, I don't mind.

I love going to Chinatown and every time we go we eat at Emperor's Choice! We ordered the sweet and sour chicken, the pork fried rice, pork spare ribs, and tomato pepper beef. All these entrees were delicious, and I was especially impressed with the spare ribs! They were sweet, tangy, and easy to eat since they were mostly off the bone. Yum! The only disappointing food we ordered were the egg rolls which were not all bad, but my mother's egg roll tasted like the cabbage was sour. Besides the food the waiter was very pleasant, the decor is less than average, and the women's bathroom toilet didn't flush...gross! Other than these few flaws, I would definitely recommend Emperor's Choice and will continue to dine there in the future.

they make decent cantonese food here bt you got to special order it. i was really scared to eat here when i sat down and noticed i was the only chinese person in this packed place and they offered chop suey and egg foo young on the menu!  looked like everyone was gobbling down the food with good cheer though. but the staff was friendlier than average chinatown and they were willing to make stuff not on the menu.  they make a really good sauteed watercress.  the chilean seabass dish is pretty good too. i liked the portraits of the various emperors on the walls but thought they should've been more grand looking.  they looked more like portraits of imperial ministers rather than the actual emperors.

Emperor's Choice is NOT a dim sum place.  They serve entrees.  While the decor could use a makeover, the food is great.  The sweet & sour chicken was possibly the best I've ever had, and the kung pao chicken is sooooooo good.  I highly recommend this place to anyone visiting Chicago's Chinatown.

I guess I can keep this one simple...Where they don't have it in cusine, they make up in service! My friends and I have been 3 or 4 times in the last month or so and have enjoyed each.  They make a great Zombie, the beef and orange peel is great and the shrimp toast makes me smile at night.   If you are looking for an off the beaten path spot that you can become a regular @, this is your place!

Tried a few places in Chinatown and this place has the best Salt and Pepper Shrimp of any of them.  Don't go crazy ordering food here or you'll go broke!  It's certainly not cheap but well worth the extra money.  We also usually get the fried rice which is also pretty good.  No question I would bring anybody here because of the great quality of the food and quick service.

I've been to this establishment twice, and can speak on a number of great things about this place.  First,  friendly and fast service -  our wait-person was fast, courteous, and helpful in directing us to choices of entries that we were pleased with.  Food came out quickly-  we ordered egg-rolls and shrimp toast for the table. The egg rolls were good; standard fare, but the shrimp toast was fantastic. Nice crunch,  minced up shrimp cooked perfectly into the bread, and deep fried.  For dinner, I ordered salt and pepper shrimp, which tasted great as well, and a generous portion to boot.     If I had to be nit-picky, the decor of the place is a bit on the dull side, but with the food as good as it is, it doesn't need fancy decorations to keep customers coming back.

Three of us had an early dinner at Emperor's Choice. We weren't very hungry and ordered two appetizers and two entrees.  The crab Rangoon was tasty but more cheese than crab. It was very hot (temperature) and large. The egg rolls were nothing to get excited about.  We opted for the Chicken Almonding and Barbecued Spareribs. The chicken was okay, not very flavorful. The ribs had a nice sweet sauce and very small bones. They were worth the visit.  We were presented with the standard fortune/almond cookie/check. The fortune cookies tasted a little stale as did the almond cookies.  The bill was $40 for three of us with tip. The restaurant was pleasant with a tiny bar and thankfully only one television. It was quite clean and tasteful. I'd give Emperor's Choice another chance.

After being confronted with a 20 minute wait with our first choice in restaurants, my party decided to play restaurant roulette in Chinatown. Spun the cylinder, up came Emperors Choice. I have been to this place before, but long ago and well before my Yelping days. I seemed to remember things being alright here. We ordered the prawn and clam bake, first time trying this, and I can't say I was thrilled with it. It was unique, but good, I don't think I would order it again though. The crab rangoon, on the other hand was really good. One of the better rangoon I've tasted. As entrees we ordered the Mongolian beef, which was laden with mushrooms , peppers, and bean sprouts,and which in my opinion have absolutely no place in a proper Mongolian beef. I would have to rate this dish a pretty good at best, even factoring out all the undesirable veggies in this dish. The beef fried rice was pretty good as well, being dragged down by too many bean sprouts. This is a sure fire way to get me to rate your fried rice from pretty good down to alright or even bad. The mushu pork wasn't like any other I've had, and not in a good way. My brother nailed it on the head when he said it was like a deconstructed egg foo young patty. I was not a fan of this dish and would call it alright. The shrimp and lobster sauce was probably the best dish we had, and that was still just good. Nothing about this place was spit out awful, yet nothing here was all that good either. I will definitely not eat here again, even with the decent service here. The prices ware the final nail in this places coffin, they have gourmet prices and hole in the wall food.
I like this place. Whenever I'm in Chinatown I like to spot by. I like it more for lunch than dinner.

Having tried almost all of the restaurants in China town in 2 years, this is one of my favourite places to eat Cantonese for 2 reasons: Good food + Nice ambience. It's small and neat with great service. The lobster is pricey but one of the best ever.

Perhaps choosing 11am on the day of the Chinese New Year Parade was not the best idea when we decided to stop in for some Chinese - the dim sum restaurant we wanted to try, Phoenix, was running an hour and a half wait.  But, no worry - there is a different restaurant on every corner and down every street in Chinatown, which arguably boasts some of the best and most authentic Chinese food in Chicago. We ended up at the Emperor's Choice, mostly because of its prime location on Wentworth Avenue in the heart of Chinatown, and possibly because of the City's Best and Zagat-rated stickers displayed on its door.  Regardless of the stickers, Emperor's Choice served plenty of high quality, moderately priced Chinese dishes in a casual yet cultural setting. A sampling of the menu included fried postickers (heaven), wonton soup (just okay), egg rolls (tasty and huge), kung pao chicken (spicy and, by far, my favorite!), sweet and sour pork (sweet and tangy with bell peppers and pineapple), Cantonese noodles (a little plain, but good for someone who doesn't want anything brimming with flavor), Mongolian beef (meaty and rich with great noodles and taste), and the Emperor's fried rice (shrimp AND chicken - definitely a dish worthy of the emperor).  There were lots of other dishes on the menu that looked equally mouth-watering. The service was exactly what you would expect at a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown - fast, friendly enough, accommodating and prompt.  You could tell that they were used to handling crowds.  The restaurant does have a full bar in case anyone is craving an adult beverage to accompany the delicious food.  To top it all off, the check is delivered with those great almond cookies that only the finest Chinese restaurants possess.  Definitely worth stopping in - parade or no parade.

Maybe it was the fact that I didnt eat all day, or perhaps it was the Navy Grog drink I had at the bar during our wait but this was the best Chinese food I had in a super long time. The wait was only 45 minutes which was pretty good considering it was during the New Years parade although we did out our name in while the parade was still going on. I was impressed with the friendliness and speed of the service. The waitress asked my girlfriends and I if we wanted seperate checks. This impressed me since most places roll their eyes when you ask for seperate checks but this woman offered! And, she didnt get our orders wrong on the checks! I had the shanghai noodles - mmm hot stuff! We all shared the shrimp fried rice, egg rolls, and crab rangoon. Yes, were hungry ladies. Everything was delicious, hot, fresh and served with a smile.

I went to this place on my last trip to chicago after reading the reviews and getting a recommendation from someone. It is in chinatown so I thought it would be at least decent. When we walked in, i noticed that other than the waiters, there wasnt a single asian person there. Bad sign in chinatown. The good thing about the food was that it wasnt too expensive and it didnt make any of us throw up. The downside was that it was extremely bland, and even things that were supposed to be spicy were almost flavorless. This is chinese food for people who usually eat at Dennys, if you want authentic chinese, go elsewhere. If this place was the choice of the emperor, it was not the emperor of an asian country.

I have brought family, friends, and visitors to this restaurant & no one leaves disappointed. It's cheap, delicious, and greasy-just how I like it, just like my men. Kiddddding! Emperor's Choice is the only restaurant I've been to in Chinatown since I moved to Chicago four years ago. Yes, it may be due to my laziness but also it's because they have the best chicken fried rice I have ever tasted. The fried rice has so much flavor & it's not that burnt flavor that I've experienced at most Chinese restaurants in the city. My mom loves the Egg Fo-Young & claims it's the best she's had.  The food is delicious & I've never been disappointed. Why not five stars? The waitstaff isn't the best, somewhat rushes you (if you look like a youngin'-like me), and I have been asked to leave while still sipping the tea I paid for so others can sit down. I think that behavior is extremely rude & it really upsets me, but I can't seem to tear myself completely from Emperor's Choice.

We are usually usure of which places to go to in Chinatown. Normally, we go to the bigger places- places EVERYONE hears about. This time, however, we decided to try something different and walked in to Emperor's Choice with no prejudices/expectations and were very happy with the choice. Our server was probably one of the nicest people in the business and even recomended a great dish. Our total bill was $34- this included several pots of hot tea, two soups, two egg rolls, and two entrees. Great prices. We will definately go back!!

Allow me to set the scene: It's 2:30pm... it's cold... I just bought a turtle the size of a quarter at a store that sold purses... I'm hungry..... As my friend Kate and I leave the purse/turtle store I ask a fellow patron; "excuse me. Do you know which way the Phoenix restaurant is?"  (racial profiling: the person happened to be Asian and I was in Chinatown, Native to the area... maybe, maybe not...) the fellow shopper replied "Yes, down this road and then to the right" "Thank you" I replied.  "If your going for dim som you need to hurry, it ends at 3pm"  he said.  "WHAT?, Well do you have any other suggestions of places to eat in the area?"  I asked.  "Yes, Try the Emperor's Choice next store, I eat lunch there everyday and it's wonderful!" He replied.  "THANKS AGAIN" I said... As for Emperor's Choice... It was okay... the portions were huge...  the wait staff was alright....  the prices were a bit high...  Oh and the best part of the whole bit.........  The Fellow patron of the neighboring shop... the nice fellow with the helpful suggestion... He just happened to be the owner of the Emperor's Choice...   Conflict of interest??  Not in Chinatown.......   LOVE IT!

I guess I really don't go to Chinatown as frequently as I thought, because the restaurant that I've always visited (to be honest, it was the first place I went and I never felt like I needed to try anywhere new) was closed, and the people in a nearby store said that it had been closed for a while. Really sad. So I was hungry and felt that if emperors would choose a place, it's good enough for a pleb like me. It was okay. I think I've heard people talk about Emperor's Choice as being awesome, and they have good reviews in the window, but I didn't think it was that great. My food was alright while I ate it, but as I was walking with my leftovers later, I couldn't stop wondering who was farting, if it was that old woman next to me who smelled so bad, and, later, if I was somehow shooting off silent-but-deadlies so silent I didn't even know. Then I realized it was my food. It seriously smelled really bad. I don't know. Yuck. My companion also felt that her food was less than awesome, and said that the meat was overcooked and too tender. I don't think that that's really a problem, but I guess for her it was. Different tastes. Anyway, I wouldn't discourage anyone from going there, and I think a lot of other people like it (we were there at a very non-peak meal time and the dining room was probably around half-capacity), but I think that next time I head to Chinatown I'll go somewhere else.

In the mood for a spicy, inexpensive seafood extravaganza?  Look no further, Emperor's Choice is the spot. This place has been here FOREVER.  It's where I take my family when my dad comes to visit, we all want seafood, and don't feel like braving the ever extending lines at the Half Shell.  Prices have increased over the years, but it's still a pretty cheap date and you can walk in with a group of 10 and be seated fairly quickly.  I'm especially fond of the Hot and Sour and Corn soups, the spicy green beans with pork, the Salt and Pepper Seafood, the Peking Crab, the shrimp and crab dumplings, the shrimp stuffed tofu, and the shrimp in the Chef's sauce.  We always go with a group and share everything around the table as the menu is pretty extensive so it can be hard to choose.  Servings are large, so you don't even really need to order appetizers unless you want to bring home leftovers. They also mix a pretty mean cocktail. Not a place I'd go for general Chinese, but a great choice for seafood.  Friendly staff, inexpensive, a really good place for a long, relaxed dinner with a group.

for a while, when my boyf would go to china town every sunday night with his friends, he always mentioned his waitress helen, and i thought it was because she was some exotic asian beauty. his friends always said that helen loved ryan and that they had become  good friends...so i thought maybe he was cheating on me with the waitress in china town!  then i went to emperor's choice and met the infamous helen. she is in her 60s, missing a few teeth and the tiniest little woman you have ever seen. i was pretty sure they weren't having an affair, but they do hug every time we come in. now that i have gotten to know helen, she always takes care of us - gives us "custom" dishes (one that my boyf created called "noah's ark" which is basically everything in the kitchen on top of crispy noodles), gives us the stickiest fried rice without onions and extra almond cookies and fortune cookies.  +the service is always good with helen! (you're my girl, helen!) ++the fried rice has a lot of egg and flavor and is amaze +++the wonton soup, egg rolls and noah's ark (ask for it if helen is your waitress, say it's ryan's dish) always deliver  you will be full when you leave, but the prices are reasonable and parking is always easy to find on wentworth.

Not only is this Emperor's Choice, it's Tom's Choice! To be honest, I'm generally wary of Chinese food.  Chinese take-out often suffers from being overly-fried, greasier than a Crisco factory, and as a result, causes me substantial gastrointestinal distress.  No wonder, a small shiver when up my spine when my co-worker chose to make Emperor's Choice the venue for a work dinner. Boy, was I surprised.  The food, particularly the seafood, was fantastic.  We dined on a life-changing whole Dungeness crab, dusted in salt and pepper, flash-fried, and brought to the table steaming hot.  The lobster was fresh, tender, and perfectly seasoned.  The non-seafood options were great as well, from the beef and broccoli (not greasy!) to the awe-inspiring wonton soup. The mai tais (yes, apparently, they are known for their mai tais) were delicious and potent.   And the service was wonderful.  Our waiter, an elderly Chinese gentleman, was friendly, hilarious, and attentive. The only negative that I can attribute to this fine restaurant is the atmosphere/decor.  It harkens back to the late 70s.  But you'll be so busy enjoying your dinner that you won't even notice.

I used to love this place.  This was the place my whole family would go and have a feast.  The food used to be top-notch, and deservedly famous for its seafood.   It's over, baby, the love is gone.  Lately, I have ordered take-ouot from this place and the food has reminded me of those cheap nasty fast-food places, less fresh, etc.   The last time I ordered - about two nights ago - I woke up at 2:00 a.m. and threw up!  It was the food.  I could tell.  I have now sworn off this place, this once grand purveyor of excellent Chinese seafood.  By the way, my family doesn't go here anymore either - quality has been generally declining.  But now, with the getting sick incident, the situation has crossed the line from merely disappointing to dangerous.   Beware. _________________________ UPDATE 2/5/09 GAVE IT ANOTHER CHANCE.  STILL SUCKS

One of the best places in Chinatown, emperor's choice tries to be upscale in its atmosphere but still manages not to be too expensive in its prices.  The waiters here must all be forced to go to charm school, because they're all friendly, funny, and fabulous.  I recommend the pea sprouts wtih shiitake mushrooms and the vegetable "xiao long" dumplings with red vinegar.  Contrary to the reviewer before me, I found plenty of vegetarian-friendly options on the menu.

Friendly, small Chinatown place. Specializes in seafood, but also makes maybe the best kung pao chicken I've ever tried. The potstickers are bigger than a baby's fist and quite delicious if the cook's having a good day. Along with the fairly standard (but more fish-centric than usual) main menu, you get a paper "village menu" of more authentic Chinese dishes, some of which seem too terrifying for mere words. Far from the worst Chinese on Wentworth, for sure. Not a good choice for vegetarians.
